reviews.review_msg: Power point teacher. Which means that you can read his slides and read the textbook as attending his lectures does not add any value. No assignments, just 3 quizzes and a final. Disappointing as it is all theory and absolutely zero practical stuff or implementation.
can't teach, can't explain, hard to understand, however he is a pretty nice guy, and seems to mark pretty easy (or maybe his TA did) Reading the textbook was a must.
Assignments are usually short but you have to know every detail in order to do well. Exams are easy. I really learned a lot from this course.
Average at best.
No Comments
Unclear about the instructions and cocky
Can anyone name a better CS prof than this guy?
He teaches the details clearly. Reading the textbook becomes much easier after his classes. Most importantly, the exam questions are consistent with the assignment. Enjoying ...

The classes in the first week were great. He touched some interesting and far from trivial topics immediately. The explanation is so clear that I had an easy time to read the textbook. I am looking forward to  more in the course.

He often talks about practical concerns and solutions, which cannot be found in our textbook. The materials are not easy, but quite useful afterall. I got something really helpful in job hunting. I realized that only after my interviews. The final grades were surprisingly nice. I wish I had spent more time on it.
Jian is a good teacher and is very helpful with any of his students' problems.  The exams were fair, but tough.  The project was long, but not too challenging.

will this guy ever understand that developing a project of that size is human impossible for a group of 2 people? The TA helps us a lots "marking" it. Take this class if you like to read the book too.. sometimes he doesn't explain some topics very clearly or he doesn't explain at all...
Very hard project, but thankfully, a fun project and the small assignment load made it easier.  Jian is a very clear prof and an excellent teacher.

Very nice in assigning the final grades. Tough and fair final exam. I did not spend enough time until the last 2 weeks. The email discussion with him was particularly helpful. If I could take it once more, I would spend more time and do much better.

Course overall is okay. His pronounciation is annoying, as are the typos in his notes. Wait until he talks about taking fuzzy dumps. He is genuinely a nice guy, but VERY high expectations  for the project. Partners should be mandatory or else you will probably fail due to lack of time. Assignments and midterm were fair. ie: give examples of...

project is just ridiculously time consuming and tedious. otherwise the course isn't too hard but it's not very interesting.
 decent prof, he knows what he's talking about but his english needs some work.
Touch midterm, but close enough to assignments. Overall challenging and interesting. One of the best in this school.
waste of time

Very interesting project, though sounds challenging. He explained the major ideas clearly, and left the details for you. Clear lectures, easy to follow. Of course, you have to read the textbook after the class. He has accent, but not too bad. Highly recommended by people in his classes before. Very nice guy overall.
He is a nice person, but not very clear on the lecture and notes

The textbook and his lecture notes sometimes dont match. He makes many mistakes. His exam/assn questions are ambiguous and marking is sometimes done on a strict basis even though there could be multiple right answers. He is very boring. On the plus side he's not too hard and exams are open book.
I find his classes boring.  I rarely attended class. He is one of the easiest instructors that I have had at SFU.  Exams are open book and questions were similar to the assignments.

The professor cares for the students but isn't great at teaching. Lectures are lengthy, doesn't have the best explanations, some content is left ambiguous at best, and examples are copied from the textbook. The content isn't hard but a lot of self-study is required with him. Weekly quizzes, plus a quiz right before a tricky midterm. Final was fair.

This man is a G. Yea the lectures are 3 hours long and boring, but the quizzes are open book, you get to bring a cheatsheet into the midterm and final, he asks fair questions based only on the slides, so reading the textbook is unnecessary. There is a little bit of confusion in the first half when it comes down to I/O costs, but generous marking!!

First half of the course was more difficult, mostly due to the lectures not being the best. However the second half was a lot easier, felt like the lectures got better as well. Homework was ambiguous at times but not too horrible. No coding for the course, only theory. Quizzes were okay, but requires attendance. Final was easy.

TLDR: unc is chill

Ke can't explain things intuitively, his accent is incomprehensible at times, 3 hour lectures were excruciating mental hurdles. Ke forces attendence by quizzes at the end of every lecture - else no one would show up

The material should be easy, if only Ke could help rather than adding confusion while wasting everyone's time. Don't take this crouse
Fair course overall, may not be the best professor at teaching but he's caring and will help if you go to office hours.

The first part of the course was taught by giving examples, but Ke never actually explained how to work through these examples and just said "this is easy, I'll let you figure it out". This effected the assignments as nobody knew exactly how to properly do the questions as we were never given a proper answer to the examples. Final is easy tho.

Professor Ke Wang is the best professor for people who want clear requirements. You can easily get really good grades in his class by understanding the textbook. He isn't overbearing. He knows all the stuff in the textbook, which is enough to handle the class. If you're looking for a lot of stuff outside class then maybe not for you.

I wouldn't say that the assignments and final were extremely easy. Some people still failed. He talks really fast and doesn't really enunciate. His slides have errors and contradicting info. However, he's available for questions and answers them well. Reasonable prof but no zoom recordings and "pass final" rule rub some students the wrong way.

3 assignments (60%) and 1 final (40%) which you must pass to pass the course. The assignments and final were extremely easy, not many references outside of the slides are needed. 

For the final, students were allowed to bring two double sided sheets of paper with anything they want on them.

The professor is quite useless at teaching though.

Must pay attention to lectures because textbook is different from slides.
Won't be sleepy in class. Has good voice.
Interrupts students while still asking question.
Doesn't record lectures.
Assignments not clear, and does not clarify (all students get same info).
40% final, must pass and mark scaled relative to class.

Awful, his teaching has gone downhill. He skips over so many concepts. His lecture slides are so sparse you are forced to read the textbook, yet the textbook is also very long and too in-depth that you won't have time. Also, the textbook is really dry. He isn't a good professor. Please take another professor.  He doesn't explain things very well.

The material is easy, but he doesn't explain them well. He is incoherent not because of the accent but because he talks fast and his thoughts are jumbled. He often interrupts students before they could finish the questions. He doesn't record lectures even though it'd help everyone involved. He cares a lot, but he's old-school and refuses to adapt.

not good enough. Jumps around slides. Modifies them in real time. Incoherent sentences. Obscure references, acronyms. Lectures are just a shell of what is found online. Just a bad experience. His accent is not the issue. His thought process is just all over the place.
Kept the course straight-forward and organized. Learned a lot in both application and theory of DBMS management and recovery.

Very heavy accent. Takes multiple tries to get out a coherent sentence. Complex concepts are rushed through without much care. While most assignment questions are straight forward, some are very ambiguous and obscure. This whole course just felt confusing and tiring. Oh, and you get scaled down. What a shame, since the content is actually good...

Ke Wang is one of my favorite profs because he is willing to help answer questions and all you need is his notes to do well. He also changes completely every quiz every term so people can't cheat and use past resources. Down side is that his English isn't that good.

Ke Wang is THE best you can have. You can literally go to his office at any time and he will help you with any question. Went there 2 hrs before quiz too. Also answers any question in class, so just ask. The TA we had was a super easy marker. The actual subject is definitely not straight forward tho. But if you have Ke, you already half passed
Boring class but clear from prof.  Expect to do bad on the first test to get the idea of how he tests.

He's loud and precise when teaching, so it's very easy to follow what he says. He always encourages questions and smiles when people ask them during class, so you can tell he just genuinely enjoys helping students. Assignments are tricky but help you learn. Exams are fair, most are 2/3 average difficulty with the last 1/3 testing very tricky stuff.

Excellent professor.  Knows the content of this course very well, as he's been teaching it for a while.  His accent may distract a few people, but overall he's pretty clear and concise.  Would take another class with him.

The prof understands material very well and always explains in simple words. He encourages students to ask questions and do exercises in order to get a better understanding of the course. Though he has a little Chinese accent, it's not a big deal I think. Overall, a hard-working and excellent prof!

HIGHLY RECOMMEND! Very good prof. Only had quizzes and final exam. Explained the material in a very clear and simple way. He encourages questions and ensures students understand the material. Must attend lectures as he explains it very well. He provides practice questions and goes through them in class.
There is no consistency in marking whatsoever. The TA clearly knew nothing about the course material

This prof is very smart and very good at teaching,he's teaching is very clear. if you actually listen to what he says, you will get the idea .He definitely good at what he does.Exam is fair. He also encourage students to ask questions too,and unlike many other prof,he 90% of time understand what your questio are and rephrase them in simpler words
Great prof!

I honestly missed most of the lectures, but I read the book, and was able to end up with an A in the course (I was lazy, or it could have been an A+). I recommend using the lecture notes as a guide and just read the book until you understand everything, or just go to lectures and listen really carefully and you'll do well.
As long as you listen and understand in the lecture, you will do great without too much effort. Midterm and Final requires thinking, not just writing out from the book.
awsome awsome prof
Tough final. did not cover too much material but not necessary mean easy...

He knows what he's talking about, but sometimes he doesn't say enough 'on purpose' to challenge you.  This is an annoying side of him.  I'm preparing for a tough final!  What do you expect for a 400 level computing course?
You'll do well in his course as long as you understand his accent.  Killer final exam, but nice curve.
No Comments
Explains things well if you're okay with the accent, but exams are killer.
So boring, nothing to do, feels like haven't learn anything

Least favourite professor in my academic career. While course content is well structured and organized, the negatives were overwhelming: Constant typos in lecture material, tests/quizzes, and assignments, lecture videos provided no value, and somewhat inconsistent marking on quizzes. I would highly recommend avoiding her classes if you can.

5 tough, assignment that build on top of each other (don't mess up the first few) + final exam. Vague feedback, hard to debug old assignments, but instructor/TAs are very responsive. The instructor genuinely cares, but has high expectations for students. VERY coding heavy, prerequisites don't do it justice. Don't take with other heavy classes.

I wish that we had homework or quizzes so that we can check how well we absorbed the materials before exams. The professor and TA really save their time by making no homework/quizzes/feedbacks, but it causes confusion for us students. It's reaally an awful learning experience for me.

Seems to me that the course has too many aims to achieve: both introductory ones and advanced ones. It's like one course trying to achieve two courses' goals. The professor just crams everything into the course without adjusting the workloads according to the limited time and students' levels.

He set high standards for students, but he didn't seem to spend enough time or make enough efforts to guarantee good logistics or fair grading. It left me the impression that our work was graded arbitrarily, in a hasty manner, and by few things.

While the professor said that he "really" wants to give us marks, the truth is rather the opposite. Minor mistakes in the projects, each can lead to deduction of 2-3 points in the final grade. So, if you have several minor mistakes, you might receive much lower-than-expected grade (for example, A- becomes B+ or B).

Some professors hold high expectations for students. However, they usually show a clear path of how to be successful in their courses by giving clear instructions. Wang's problem is not tough grading, but not giving useful instructions. You'll be surprised by the reasons why the marks are deducted.
Prof Wang is a tough grader. In fact, I haven't met any other professor at SFU who is so harsh in grading.

For knowledge: he didn't explain things well, and he skipped key concepts. Online resources can offer better learning experience.

For grade: Wang is an especially harsh grader to be avoided.

The course was not extremely bad, but the logistics was toxic. He changed his mind/policy many times without formal announcements, and certain policies were made just before the final deadline. I am not a fan of such lazy and disorganized manner.

Professor Wang never give us clear and up-front instructions so that we have a guideline of what's expected. The feedbacks are released too late. Without an idea of what are his actual requirements, you'll find his grading arbitrary. Seems that he graded at the last minute, and it's graded by few things.

Learning from a demanding, irresponsible, and unpredictable professor can be frustrating. If you really can't avoid him, you still can try to get the best scores from all other courses, and that will demonstrate to the world that you did excellent work, and the poor grading is his problem.

On average, you are expected to get B- or C+ from him, while other CS professors would give you an average of A-. It's not just some students are falling behind, it impacts everybody. The exceedingly low average grade clearly indicates that he can't teach well and he's just not responsible enough for teaching matters.

Some project topics require us to use high performance computers for experiments. No one tell you this, but you lose marks if you don't do it. I don't think it's fair that we got lower marks because of having no access to a good computer. I'm not satisfied that prof never make instructions clear and fair.

Surprised by the number of negative reviews. There is a lot of content covered but the lectures, projects and instructions are well organized and fair. Project builds on top of other modules so it can be difficult to catch up if something goes wrong early. Overall I enjoyed building the toy database and learnt a lot from the course.
Life is hard. Don't make it harder by learning with him. "Why is the score so low? What did you do?" "I worked hard but the professor is Tianzheng Wang. He's impossible."
Horrible. Maybe he's good at research, but he definitely doesn't care about teaching and students. Avoid if you can.

I'm grateful that I don't find a second GPA destroyer like this one at SFU. For those who want to learn database: he's not the only professor who teaches this course. You have better alternative options.
Prof Wang successfully minimizes his efforts and maximizes students' frustrations.

I strongly discourage you from taking his course. I can't think of another professor at SFU who gave me such bad learning experience. Our work was graded carelessly. Hardworking was not rewarded and minor mistakes can be punished harshly. Since there's no homework/instructions/grading criteria, we are punished for his laziness and awful logistics!

I've been at SFU for 4 yrs and I've overcome many difficult courses. I have confidence tackling difficult courses, not difficult professors. tzwang is definitely the most difficult professor (not one of) I've ever seen. He just made everything unnecessarily hard because he didn't do his job properly. He's second to none in creating low morale.

Taking course with him you'll get much heavier workload and much lower grade. But he did this for your good, right? Even if he doesn't explain things clearly and doesn't check details for fair grading, you did learn a lot and you'll have something funny on your transcript. Isn't that great? Isn't that the perfect course to take?

He didn't care if students absorb the lecture stuff. He didn't give useful, clear instructions. Some feedbacks were released too late, and grade was based on few things. I doubt if he put even minimal efforts in teaching.

He made the course unnecessarily hard by giving vague instruction, few feedback and non-sense grading. He has constantly proved that he's failing at teaching yet he's proud of that. Don't let this guy ruin your GPA or your confidence in learning database. Database is not difficult, he is. He would punish students for his own faults. JUST AVOID!!

Some graders are tough cuz they care about ur success in future. This one just grade by few things and pick out minor mistakes to deduct marks heavily. He doesn't care about students, just want to spend no time in teaching.

I have a rubric for prof wang. Being absent for 2 lectures: -2; Dismiss class before scheduled time >2 times: -2; No clear instructions before assignments: -4; Give low average grade without good reason: -4. Overall: -7/5. There's no rescale because that's not fair to other professors. I'd give a high score but this is the rightful thing to do.
This is the WORST prof at SFU. Giving him 1/5 rating is unfair to other professors receiving 1/5. His rating should be something like - 1/5.

Only those who have already learned the stuff before taking the course can get a merely fine grade. He's not teaching. He just wants everyone to be an expert and contribute to his own projects. Indeed he's lazy and irresponsible.

After midterm, he suggested those who earned 20%-30% in the exam to "work harder". He said that if you put everything there in the report it will be fine. It is funny and unrealistic. But it is also EVIL because he knew crystal clear in his mind that he won't let them pass and he still gave them false hope and tortured them.

Giving students extremely low scores is not a way to prove that "I am the best, I am too good to be at SFU". No clear instructions, few feedbacks, unrealistic syllabus/learning goals, requiring expertise as an intermediate course... these all indicate poor design of the course and neglect of students. It is so pathetic and pathological.

Difficulty should be 6 out of 5. Don't care to improve teaching, provide feedbacks, improve logistics, or make policies clear. Average grade is much lower than other courses at SFU. There are way better database courses online from really top professors. Work harder and get a lower grade from him is the last choice you might want.
First course that I failed in 4 years.
Disappointed
Terrible
One of the worst prof I've taken so far. His assignments are really difficult. This course also had a negative impact on my other courses. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM.
I am just astonished how misleading the reviews can be ... Look at those reviews below with full marks, then think about quite the opposite, which might be closer to reality.
Prof wang is good and helping but lectures are low quality which confused me many times. There is a lot of coding in this course and unrealistic difficult grading standards.

He's great. Lectures are efficient and very coherent. Most importantly, attendance is not required but participation is rewarded. Responsive and good choice of TAs. Assignments and quizzes are challenging and educational. Rare to find profs as good as he in SFU CS department.

Awesome prof. He explains the concepts quite well and if you have more questions he is approachable to ask. The database project is very hard and he warns us to be prepared and to drop if we find the first milestone really hard. (many people dropped and complained because they literally started milestones 1-2 days it was due and we had 3 weeks...)
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. THE DATABASE PROJECT IS DAMN NEAR IMPOSSIBLE. OVER 40% HAVE ALREADY DROPPED THE COURSE. IT'S ALL IN C AND GUESS WHAT THAT'S WHAT YOUR GRADE WILL BE.

I liked the project where we built a database engine - it was good to see how to apply some of the theory (its a lot of locks). I do wish we implemented query parsers/optimizers. The lectures were long and a touch on the dry side (and i find many of the topics interesting).

Very project heavy, but you learn a lot. You implement a database and it's worth 85% of your mark, he also gives chance for bonus marks and if you do well he gives you a good mark, no scaling (his words). Quizzes weren't hard if you attended lectures and studied a tiny bit, no final. Learned a lot
Hard projects, quiz beyond expected difficulty

To be honest, this class was not for me. I am not a fan of low level programming or using C++. However, if this is what you do like, then you will love this class. The assignments are really tough if you do not know C++. The profs instructions were not extremely helpful. The lecture notes are also very dense, almost unreasonably so.

This is without a doubt THE best course currently offered that I have had the pleasure to take at SFU. The group project is well structured, but start early! tzwang has proven lecture after lecture that he really understands the content and can _easily_ answer any/all questions. His content is very well structured - one of the best profs at SFU!

You get to learn many programming techniques while doing the project, the class material is not hard but the challenge is to memorize all of them. as for the project, he literally said "if you can do well in this project, you can theoretically do well in any other programming project." So if you can survive, very interesting and useful class.
Nice person but failed to explain many concepts clearly

John is a great lecturer, however, the assignments are rather difficult in comparison to what's covered in class. Good thing he responds to emails very quickly, even on weekends! Studying for exams is fairly challenging as there is so much content. The cumulative final has more than 600 slides worth of information. The class average was C+.

During the first half of the term, he seems to be managing the course well. However, as the difficulty level increases in the second half, he appears to struggle to keep up. he hasn't adequately prepared for his lectures. when encountering challenging concepts he is not familiar with, he just quickly glosses over them.

The ppt slides are impressively well made. Assignments and quizzes help students learn the material. Sometimes felt the lecture covered too many details, but the exams were fair without trick questions. He's very responsive and helpful to student questions. I couldn't put much effort but could see he's a knowledgable and great prof!
His videos are very vogue, almost everything in his assignments, you can't find it in his notes, and there are very few resources you can find by online or reading the textbook.

His pre-recorded videos are terrible since he sometimes speaks very quietly and sometimes very loud.. and tends to speak fast when the materials are harder to understand. His assignments are even worse, we had one exercise, one quiz, one report, and one assignment all due within a week.
